properties.status: Demolished for development. Location now occupied by a high-rise condo apartment called the Claridge Plaza. Chapel removed and reconstructed in the National Gallery of Canada.
properties.history: Established in 1869 as a bilingual school for girls, the convent expanded with a new building in 1888 to accomodate enrollment demands. In 1970, after dropping enrollment and the secularization of Ontario education, the Sisters of Charity decided to sell the convent for development. The developer, Glenview Realty Ltd., initially planned to include the existing building in the new development. However, the developer decided to remove the building and applied for a demolition permit on March 14, 1972. The NCC tried to find a solution to save the Chapel however the City issued a permit on April 21, 1972.

properties.status: Location now occupied by the Westin Hotel.
properties.history: The second oldest hotel in Ottawa, the property was purchased by Samuel Norton in 1848 who opened Norton's Tavern. The hotel had several names until 1911 when it was renamed the Federal Hotel and expanded to five storeys. It was renamed again to the King Edward and finally the Grand Hotel. The building was given heritage designation in 1978. However, according to a 1980 Ottawa Citizen article, it was slated for demolition in January 1981 and was subsequently demolished before construction began on the Rideau Centre in 1983.

properties.status: Demolished for Elgin Street expansion.
properties.history: The first Knox Church was located at the corner of Daly Avenue and Cumberland. Due to overcrowding, a new church, this building, was built in 1874. The interior of the church contained 12 stained glass windows and could seat over 1,100 people. In the 1930s, part of Prime Minister MacKenzie King's plan for beautifying the capital included the widening of Elgin Street. As the church was in the way of the expansion, the congregation moved in 1932 to its current location at the corner of Elgin and Lisgar Streets and the church was demolished in 1938. Before demolition, the church was used during the Depression for public relief.

properties.status: Demolished to make room for Confederation Square.
properties.history: With the construction of the Russell Theatre, which had a seating capacity of about 1,500, Ottawa had its first major theatre hall. Its interior included 2 semi-circular balconies, 10 boxes, an immense curtain separating the audience and the stage and a lighting system that permitted various colour effects. On April 8,1901, the theatre was destroyed by fire but was rebuilt to its original architecture and reopened on October 5, 1901. The theatre closed its doors on April 14, 1928 and was demolished by the Federal District Commission (precursor to the National Capital Commission) to make way for Confederation Square and the National War Memorial.

properties.status: Burned and demolished. Location now occupied by the National War Memorial.
properties.history: A hotel on the site dates back to about 1845. It was originally known as Campbell's House and the structure was 3-stories. In 1864, as civil servants migrated to the new capital and needed a place to stay, James A. Gouin bought the hotel and renamed it the Russell House Hotel. The hotel reached its peak during the 1880s and 1890s. Many Victorian luminaries, such as Oscar Wilde, Lilly Lantry, Lillian Russell and Jim Corbett, were all guests at the Russell House. Sir MacKenzie Bowell lived their for 17 years and Sir Wilfrid Laurier lived there for 10 years. The Russell House Hotel closed its doors in 1925 due to competition with the Chateau Laurier. The federal government purchased the hotel in 1927. On 14 April 1928, a fire destroyed the hotel. No cause was ever determined. The remains of the hotel were removed by 10 November 1928.

properties.status: Closed its doors on 31 August 1957. Location now occupied by the Thomas D'Arcy McGee Building, formerly the Royal Bank Building.
properties.history: The first meal prepared entirely by electricity in Canada was at the Windsor Hotel in 1892. The meal was prepared by Thomas Ahearn using his patented electric oven. At the turn of the 20th century, the hotel was named Daniel's Hotel after Samuel Daniels, a contractor on the St. Lawrence and Ottawa Railway. Around 1909, the hotel was sold to John Grimes and in 1915 it was taken over by Michael Hart and then by his wife after his death in 1935. The building was damaged by a fire in 1957 and was closed the same year on August 31. After demolition, a Royal Bank building was built circa 1961. This building was demolished around 1981 and replaced with the current building.

Ahearn was co-founder and president of the Ottawa Electric Railway Company, instrumental in the development of electricity in Ottawa, built the first "electric oven" in Ottawa, and became  chairman of the Federal District Commission, predecessor of the National Capital Commission. He called the property "Buenavista".

properties.history: The first railway station in Ottawa, the Sussex Street Station was opened sometime in December 1854 or January 1855. A fire occurred on 7th May 1860 which was later deemed to be arson. Due to its proximity to Rideau Hall, the station was regularly used for regal and vice-regal occasions, such as the arrival of Prince Arthur in October 1869. The station was in use until the line was abandoned in 1964, The last train to use the Sussex Street Station was on 12th June 1964.

properties.status: Location now occupied by Bronson Park.
properties.history: Constructed as a conversion (or replacement) of the home of David Manchester, it was sold to a real estate dealer named John Y. Caldwell in the Spring of 1911, with the intent of demolishing the apartments. However, he then decided to sell the apartments, except as a factory. The apartments were given the name "Broadview" in 1914. In July of 1924, a fire broke out in the basement and spread through the dumbwaiter. The fire was contained with minimal damage and all occupants escaped unharmed. In 1940, the federal government bought the property and removed it 4 years later to make way for the Greber Plan.

properties.buildingName: Residence of Sir Robert Laird Borden, 'Glensmere'
properties.status: Demolished for development. Location now occupied by the Watergate Apartments.
properties.history: Built by Hayter Reed, the Deputy Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs, it was later purchase by Sir Robert Borden in 1907 while he was still Leader of the Opposition. Borden lived in the house until his death in 1937 while his widow remained in the house until the early 1940s. It was purchased by the Chinese Nationalist Government in 1942 who remained in the building until it was sold in 1969 to Danbury Developments Ltd. The Canadian Government considered purchasing the house as an historic site. However, the house was demolished to build the Watergate Apartments.

photos.caption: Front view of Glensmere, Sir Robert Borden's residence.

properties.history: Opened in 1894 with 23 beds, the building cost $9,000 to build. The hospital closed in 1924 when it was amalgamated with the Ottawa Civic Hospital. From 1926 to 1943, it housed the Protestant Children's Hospital. After much efforts to raise funds, The Protestant Children's Hospital closed its doors. The board of the Children's Hospital held its last meeting on July 7, 1943.

properties.history: Although the St. Patrick’s Orphanage and Asylum was established on December 17, 1865, the building itself was completed in May 1873 after it was decided that a permanent facility was needed for the asylum. In 1884, an annex was added to the building. In 1933, St. Patrick's changed its name to St. Patrick's Home and in 1961, they changed focus to only care for the elderly. On June 4, 1964, the home moved to 2865 Riverside Drive. The building at the corner of Laurier and Kent was probably demolished not longer after since by 1965, a new high-rise was well under construction according to the 1965 air photos provided on the geoOttawa website.

properties.status: Demolished for construction of government buildings. Now occupied by the West Memorial Building.
properties.history: The residents of Nicholas Sparks. Nicholas Sparks purchased land in the 1820s that stretched from Bronson Avenue to Nicholas Street and Wellington to Slater Streets. At the time of purchase, the area was entirely forest. However, with the building of the canal, Sparks sold much of his land to the engineers and workers of the canal and also to the church. From Sparks' death in 1862 until its demolition, the building had changed owners several times. There was an effort to preserve the building by the Women's Canadian Historical Society, however all attempts to save the building were denied by the federal government. The government did save plans and photos of the building as well as some of the wood-work.

properties.history: This building was the Bank of British North America from at least 1875 to sometime between 1901 and 1909 based on City of Ottawa directories. From 1909 to 1912, the building contained the Hawkesbury Lumber Co. Ltd. offices. After 1913, the building was used for federal government sevices. From 1913 to at least 1916, the building was used by Customs Preventive Services. In 1923, the building is listed as the Office of the Chief Electoral Officer. When the building was demolished in 1936, Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King obtained the archway and erected it on his estate in the Gatineau Hills. He also took some of the stones from the building to construct ruins on his estate. The archway and ruins are at "Moorside" at the Mackenzie King Estate in Gatineau Park.

properties.status: Destroyed by fire. Location now occupied by a new Sacred Heart Church built in the early 80s.
properties.history: The church, built in 1910, replaced a previous church structure which was consumed by fire on June 10, 1907. The first Mass in the church was on Christmas Eve in 1910 and it was inaugurated on October 29, 1911 which included Sir Wilfrid Laurier in attendance. The church burned in 1978 due to an electrical malfunction. The vital records of the church were saved due to being stored in the basement. A new church was built on the site between 1980-1981.

properties.status: Location now occupied by Confederation Park.
properties.history: Built in 1907, this third arena built by the Dey family was home to the Ottawa Hockey Club (Ottawa Senators) from 1908 to 1923. At the time, it was the largest arena in Canada. Its capacity was about 7,000. Esther Sherwood leased the land for $166.66 per month for 20 years. The arena opened on January 11, 1908 with a game between Ottawa and the Montreal Wanderers. The last Senators game played at the arena was on March 10, 1923. At the end of its lease in 1927, the federal government demolished the arena to extend the Driveway to Sparks Street and add exit ramps onto Slater Street.

photos.caption: View of Laurier Avenue looking west. The arena is the large building on the right of the photo.

properties.status: Burned in 1979. Foundation remains and is now used as a garage.
properties.history: Opened on 17 January 1888, the initial enrollment of the school was 254 students. The school was originally going to be called Wellington Ward Primary School but the name Percy Street School stuck. With the expansion of the surrounding neighbourhood, the school was enlarged in 1909 and again in 1930. By the 1960s, the school was considered too archaic and closed. For a decade, the building was used for storage while different ideas were considered for the site, such as a new Glashan Public School or a youth drug treatment centre. In 1978, the site was sold to the City of Ottawa for $250,000 and the city leased the site to Centretown Citizens Ottawa Corporation (CCOC) for 90 years. On 17 April 1979, the building was engulfed in a fire set by an arsonist. As part of the CCOC plans, the foundation of the school was used as a parking structure with a landscaped deck on top.

photos.caption: Southeast view of Percy Street School.

sources.name: It's Back to School! Remembering the old Percy Street Public School
